title: Fractionating face processing via prosopagnosia
abstractText: Face processing is one of the key abilities allowing humans to engage in extraordinarily sophisticated social interactions. This research project is an unprecedented opportunity to understand the cognitive architecture of face processing by testing a large cohort of participants with face processing impairments, a condition called prosopagnosia. Our research web site (http://www.faceblind.org) has now been contacted by more than 2800 prosopagnosics. The majority of these cases result from developmental problems including some with a genetic basis, but other cases were caused by brain damage suffered in adulthood. Testing these individuals with a carefully designed battery of face processing tasks will reveal the dissociations and associations that exist between different face processing abilities (identity, emotion, attractiveness) and will test the predictions of the Bruce and Young model of face processing (1986). More generally, it will speak to fundamental issues in cognitive psychology such as the relationship between acquired and developmental disorders and the nature of cognitive specialization. It is also hoped that media attention on the research will increase public awareness of prosopagnosia, as its prevalence is much greater than previously realised (possibly 1-2 per cent of the population) and yet the public and even many health care providers remain unaware of it.
impactText: Our findings have been cited in many papers investigating developmental prosopagnosia and face processing more generally. Education,Healthcare Cultural,Societal,Policy & public services
findingsText: We learned more about the relationship between different face processing abilities. Yes, others will build on this work. (I'm keeping this short because I submitted an end of grant award years ago.) Education,Healthcare
